player_decision.reason: Heads-up with A9s is strong; apply pressure to the short-stacked big blind (45) with a minimum raise to gain fold equity and good postflop equity if called.

You’re in the big blind with Ts7c and face a 40 bet from the opener. Calling 20 to see the flop gives roughly 80 total in the pot, so break-even is about 25% equity. With a weak hand but reasonable equity and a large opponent stack, folding is costly and shoving/raising is too risky. Call to realize any potential on the flop.

With Ts7c on a Td 7s Ks flop you have middle two-pair and only 25 chips left. Shoving maximizes fold equity and protects your stack in a tournament setting, risking the minimum with a marginal hand but potentially doubling up hard if called.

Pot is 105 and I only need to call 25 (break-even ≈19%). With Ad9d on Td7sKs I have ace-high plus backdoor diamond/runner-runner outs and likely >19% equity vs Charlie’s wide calling range. Calling is a cheap, +EV play; no need to overcommit with AllIn.

Charlie is already all-in and I have already matched his bet. Betting now cannot make him fold and would only risk extra chips unnecessarily. I have Ace-high plus a strong nut-flush draw (Ad9d with Td and 4d on board), so calling (checking through) preserves my stack and sees the river to decide the winner.

Charlie is already all-in for a small amount. I have only Ace-high (Ad9d) and no strong draw; calling contests the main pot while preserving my stack. Betting or shoving would only create an uncallable side pot and needlessly risk chips — preserve stack to continue aiming to win the tournament.
